CRUD JDBC
Documentation for CRUD in JDBC connections

by Leo Ketola

Leo Ketola 08/12/2024

1

1. Introduction

The purpose of this documentation is to present how to connect to a
database through JDBC and how to use SQL queries inside Java.

2. Prerequisites

For the purpose of this manual we'll be using an existing MYSQL database. This
guide is created for Maven projects, this requires dependencies for the
pom.xml file.

<dependency>

<groupId>com.mysql</groupId>

<artifactId>mysql-connector-j</artifactId>

<version>8.1.0</version>

</dependency>

3. Establishing a connection

Before connecting we must know our database’s name, port, username,
password to form our connection url. For simplicity for future modifications we
should create static final variables for all our info. To select your database
replace mysql after jdbc: and replace with the corresponding string.

private static final String username = "root";

private static final String password = "password";

private static final String hostname = "localhost";

private static final String port = "3306";

private static final String database = "databaseName";

private static final String url = "jdbc:mysql://" + hostname + ":" + port +
"/" + database + "?useSSL=false";

"jdbc:mysql://" + hostname + ":" + port + "/" + database + "?username=" +
username + "&password=" + password;

Leo Ketola 08/12/2024

2

With this information we will be creating a connection using the Connection
interface imported from java.sql. To create a connection we must get a
connection from the DriverManager with getConnection(). Its parameters
can be a single url with the necessary parameters like:

getConnection.(url);

Or with the url, username and password as parameters:

getConnection.(url, username, password);

Getting a connection can throw a SQLException, so we can throw it in the
function declaration or surround it with a try/catch block. Setting the
AutoCommit to false makes our database not save any changes to the
database unless explicitly told so with commit();

public Connection connectMySQL() {

Connection connex = null;

try {

connex = DriverManager.getConnection(url, username, password);

connex.setAutoCommit(false);

} catch (SQLException ex) {

ex.printStackTrace();

}

return connex;

}

This function returns the Connection to be used. Once we have our
Connection object we can start using it!

Connection connex = connectMySQL();

Leo Ketola 08/12/2024

3

4. Using the connection

We can basically use all SQL inside Java now. Like inserting rows into tables,
deleting rows, making SELECT queries or modifying rows.

4.1. Basics

4.1.1. Statement

First, we must explain what a Statement is. Statement is an interface that will
be created by our jdbc connection, with this Statement we will be able to
execute queries and get their return values. When creating the object we
only create a statement and do not give it any instructions yet, those are
given in the executeQuery in the form of a String.
